frameDefinitions: The Means action by which a deprofiled agent (the Protagonist) has attempted to achieve a Goal, is finished and the actual outcome of the Means action has been resolved, so that it either specifically matches the Protagonist's intent (e.g. success) or does not match it (e.g. failure).
A Speaker addresses an Audience on a particular Topic.
A stretch of linguistic discourse or a Text that a Communicator produces has a Topic that it is about.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
The answer to a Question is under discussion in a Group, which still  has a difference of opinion among its members.
Two (or more) people (the Interlocutors, also encodable as Interlocutor_1 and Interlocutor_2) talk to one another.
frameExamples: McNamara <t>addressed</t> congress on the state of affairs of the Department of Defense.
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
Firstly, it is quite clear the <t>issue</t> in this context was not so much apostasy as much as it was treason.
I would rather <t>discuss</t> politics with anyone but him.
listRoleDefinitions: The action that the agent undertakes to achieve the <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is what the agent attempts to achieve by performing the <fen>Means</fen> action.
An entity directed by the agent as part of the <fen>Means</fen> action in order to accomplish the <fen>Goal</fen>.
A participant function of an <fen>Instrument</fen> or <fen>Means</fen> in a particular event or in events of a particular kind.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the attempt succeeds or fails
The place where <fen>Means</fen> action succeeds or fails.
The person or persons to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> delivers their text.
The person who orally delivers a text about a <fen>Topic</fen> to a passive <fen>Audience</fen>.
What the text that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces is about.
The <fen>Time</fen> describes when the speaking occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location where the speaking occurs.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is what a <fen>Text</fen> is about.
A set of propositions that is coherent in being about a <fen>Topic</fen>
The <fen>Communicator</fen> is the person who has produced a <fen>Text</fen> on a <fen>Topic</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> produces <fen>Text</fen> on a <fen>Topic</fen>.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
The <fen>Question</fen> is an open proposition the answer to which is under dispute.
The time interval during which the <fen>Question</fen> exists as a problem for the <fen>Group</fen>.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as compared with <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen> is generally encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>.  Thus a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that of <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Interlocutors</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> refers to the semantically and grammatically less prominent group.  It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by <ment>with</ment>).  Note that it is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents. For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Interlocutors</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Interlocutors</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Discussion frame, it is possible for the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.

<fen>Topic</fen> expresses the subject that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> are trying to come to some agreement about.  It may refer, for example, to an undesirable issue that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> want to have the proper response to, or it may refer more directly to an unresolved question.
The time at which the discussion takes place.
The location at which a discussion takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>His daring, almost reckless, move</fex> succeeded and he lived to fight another day.

This move succeeded <fex>in securing trade concessions and the release of imprisoned
American sailors</fex>.
All of my usual source books seemed incomplete, but <fex>your website</fex> did the trick!
The machine was successful <fex>as a reconnaissance vehicle</fex>.
But it did the trick <fex>at the time</fex>.
A similar strategy, perhaps even bloodier, did the trick <fex>in El Salvador</fex>.
He lectured <fex>to the officers of the Scots Guard</fex>  in  1929.
<fex>You</fex> have to sermonize about the good times
He was the Director: he could lecture <fex>on whomever he liked</fex>.
Sue bought a <fex>book</fex> about Pennsylvania
In his book, <fex>Smithers</fex> discusses cotton production.
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
The issue is <fex>who will have control of Iraq's rich oil resources</fex>.

The issue <fex>at the time</fex> was whether or not to relocate the Rennes-based part of
the team to California.
<fex>The President</fex> conferred with his top advisor.
The President debated <fex>with his top advisor</fex>.
(1) <fex>The President and his advisor</fex> discussed the Venezuelan situation briefly before the summit.
The President and his top advisors discussed <fex>the scandal</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex> the participants discussed taking down the last trade barriers without consensus.
We just conferred for a couple of hours <fex>up in her room</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Liberation Army of Bangla Desh
midnight on the morning of March 26,1971
the Dalil Potro to The Statesman
the Liberation Army of Bangla Desh
the evening of that same day
The Voice of Independent Bangla Desh
